hypothesis_content.title: Stress Regime Exhaustion Gap Fade
hypothesis_content.statement: During a STRESS regime, the appearance of a large downside gap (open >2.5% below prior close) that is partially filled within the same trading day (price trades above the midpoint of the gap) indicates panic exhaustion and presents a high-risk, high-reward mean reversion trade back towards the pre-gap close.
hypothesis_content.rationale: Stress regimes are characterized by panic and illiquidity. A large gap represents an overnight sentiment extreme. A rapid intraday recovery of half the gap suggests the panic was overdone and met with aggressive buying (e.g., short covering, contrarian bids), providing a short-term snap-back opportunity. This is a pure liquidity-driven reversal.
entry_conditions: Market opens with a gap down of >2.5% from previous day's close
Price trades above the midpoint of the gap [(Prior Close + Open)/2] during the first 4 hours of the session
1-hour RSI(14) falls below 20 at the open and then rises above 30

exit_conditions.take_profit: Price reaches 90% of the previous day's close (90% gap fill)
exit_conditions.stop_loss: Price makes a new intraday low below the opening gap level

hypothesis_content.falsification_criteria: More than 45% of such intraday recoveries fail and close at or near the day's low, indicating the buying was insufficient and the stress-driven selling pressure is still dominant.
